results.title: Telephone presentation and time management
results.brief_description: As a medium for information exchange, the telephone is constantly evolving, and so too are the techniques we use to make this powerful tool work for us in the business community. It’s important that we master these techniques. This video aims to improve your presentation and time management with the telephone in terms of your voice (variations in tone, pitch and volume), spelling out difficult names or numbers, good listening, mood, techniques for putting callers at ease and etiquette for receiving business calls using “hold” options and note taking.

results.title: Telephone factor
results.brief_description: The telephone has long since become the foremost means of communication throughout the world. The film shows a wide range of modern telephone techniques. In an attractive presentation which takes the audience on a trip around the world, it shows the numerous possibilities of the telephone applied to all walks of life, from the private household to international enterprises.

results.title: Telephone exchange
results.creator_credit: Technical and Scientific Films, Denis Ward and David Cons
results.brief_description: Shows by diagrams, models and live action the basic working of an automatic telephone exchange. Comparisons with a manual exchange. Demonstrates working of a uniselector, dialling a number and the subsequent connection. Shows correct method of dialling.

results.title: Telephone etiquette
results.brief_description: Telephone etiquette is vitally important in ensuring effective information flow. This short instructional video covers the main points in telephone etiquette, including identification of the caller/receiver of the call; politeness; using answering machines; tact and discretion and how to deal with difficult customers.

results.title: Telecommunications: behind the scene
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Bill Brind and Andy Thomson
results.brief_description: An indication of the extent and importance of Canada’s telecommunications network for air and sea navigation and overseas communications. Designed for the general audience, the film illustrates the operations of the four divisions of the Telecommunications and Electronic Branch of Canada’s Ministry of Transport, serving public, private and military airports, coastal marine stations, weather ships, and the Arctic. On-the-spot examples are informative and impressive.

results.title: Telecommunications and industrial electronics
results.creator_credit: RMIT. Communications Industries Division and Wolfgang Kress
results.brief_description: Illustrates the wide application of training received during courses in communications and electronics at RMIT. Looks at the work of technicians employed by the PMG, television stations, the SEC, Bureau of Meteorology, oil refineries, electronic equipment manufacturers, and the work of an audio-visual technician. Indicates the importance and variety of these jobs.

results.title: Telecommunications 2000: who cares?
results.brief_description: Shows aspects of the work of the National Telecommunications Planning Branch of Telecom Australia, which culminated in the publication of their report ‘Telecom 2000’. Depicts the reaction of people faced with forecasts of rapid changes in telecommunications technology, and explores the dilemmas facing the provider of telecommunications if he wishes to seriously meet real social needs.

results.title: Telecom tower
results.creator_credit: CTC TV, Telecom Australia and Christina Hunniford

results.title: Teja: a Sikh priest
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Tom Manefield and Michael Rubetzki
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our multicultural society”
Describes the Indian Sikh community in Woolgoolga, in New South Wales, and Teja Singh, the community priest. Explores his role in the preservation of the culture, traditions and religion of the old life in India, and his view of the necessary changes and adaptations that the future will bring.
